# Best wireless headphones of 2020

The future is wireless. The future is now.

[![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a16297df290f5eece60f7db12a14cf8b?s=36&d=mm&r=g)by
Adam Molina](https://www.soundguys.com/author/adammolina/)July 10, 2020

18

[](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https://www.soundguys.com/best-
wireless-headphones-2595/ "Share on Twitter")
[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?app_id=598473026880919&u=https://www.soundguys.com/best-
wireless-headphones-2595/ "Share on Facebook")

[ ](https://tyvm.ly/gZVttGM)

Best All-Around

8.6

### Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT

By Audio-Technica

[Check Price](https://tyvm.ly/gZVttGM)

  * Sound quality
  * Excellent batter life
  * Folds for transport
  * Bluetooth 5
  * aptX HD support

  * Price
  * Heat buildup due to non-breathable ear pad material

The Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT are no-nonsense Bluetooth headphones that sound
great, last forever, and give you the option of wired listening.

[View Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-
review-22327/)

[ ](https://tyvm.ly/9Img)

Best Durability

8.5

### V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex

By V-Moda

[Check Price](https://tyvm.ly/9Img)

  * Military-grade durability
  * Complete customization
  * AAC and aptX
  * Hi-res certified, zero latency (wired only)
  * Integrated amp/DAC

  * Expensive
  * Some discomfort

If you need headphones that are durable, the V-Moda Crossfade 2 Wireless Codex
are the cans to get. They’re MIL-STD-810G tested and if something does go
awry, you’re covered by V-Moda’s Immortal Life Program.

[View Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/v-moda-crossfade-2-wireless-
codex-18345/)

[ ](https://tyvm.ly/eYwk)

Best Active Noise Cancelling

8.8

### Sony WH-1000XM3

By Sony

[Check Price](https://tyvm.ly/eYwk)

  * Active noise cancelling
  * LDAC codec support
  * Comfortable
  * USB Type-C

  * Price

Virtually identical to the model it replaces, incremental upgrades on a great
pair of Sony headphones isn't exactly a bad thing.

[View Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/sony-wh-1000xm3-wireless-
bluetooth-headphones-review-19824/)

[ ](https://geni.us/xX7c8Te)

Best design

8.5

### Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700

By Bose

[Check Price](https://geni.us/xX7c8Te)

  * Slick design
  * Great ANC 
  * Good sound
  * Battery life

  * Price
  * No folding hinges
  * Not as comfortable as QC35s before them

While they're not perfect, the Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700 are
exactly the update that Bose needed. They have a great new design and work
great for almost everything.

[View Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/bose-noise-cancelling-
headphones-700-24897/)

[ ](https://tyvm.ly/fkKpr)

Bang for your Buck

8.1

### Anker Soundcore Vortex

By Anker

[Check Price](https://tyvm.ly/fkKpr)

  * aptX-compatible
  * 20-hour battery life
  * Comfortable

  * Weak bass
  * Lacking clarity

Though its appearance is somewhat uninspiring, the Vortex offers excellent
features like aptX-compatibility, a 20+ hour battery life, and stable
connectivity. This is a rare breed of value-packed headphones.

[View Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/anker-soundcore-vortex-
review-17679/)

Next time you get on a flight, take a look around. I’m willing to bet that one
of the most common types of headphones you’ll see are wireless headphones. We
still have our doubts when it comes to Bluetooth headphones ([especially
Chris](https://www.soundguys.com/5-reasons-not-to-buy-bluetooth-
headphones-12150/)), but it’s hard to deny that
[Bluetooth](https://www.soundguys.com/ultimate-guide-to-bluetooth-
headphones-20019/) has come a long way from when it was first announced. Not
only do some of the best wireless headphones sound great, but they also come
with a number of useful features.

_Editor’s note: this list was updated on July 10, 2020, to address an FAQ
about in-ear options._

## The best wireless headphones are Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT

Audiophiles and audio enthusiasts know [Audio-
Technica](https://www.soundguys.com/best-audio-technica-headphones-22314/):
it’s a prolific premium audio company that’s proven itself time and time again
in the professional industry. Audio-Technica hits it out of the park with its
wireless headphone debut.

## Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT

[Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-
review-22327/)

Best All-Around

![](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-
ath-m50xbt-switch-1024x575.jpg)

  *   *   *   *   *   *   * 

Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT

8.6

[](https://tyvm.ly/gZVttGM)

If you liked the[ ATH-M50x](https://www.soundguys.com/audio-technica-
ath-m50x-592/), you’ll love the M50xBT. It may be cliche to say, but these
headphones take everything we love about the wired version and feature it in
the wireless version. Save for the newly added playback controls, the
headphones are nearly identical to their wired brethren. For better or worse,
this means they feature the same synthetic padding, which remains a bit thin.
That said, the headband is well reinforced, by its metal frame. Folding the
ear cups in and up results in a compact, travel-friendly form, too.

[![Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT frequency response
chart.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-
ath-m50xbt-frequency-response-
chart-1024x672.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-frequency-response-
chart.jpg)

Although the ATH-M50xBT headphones are a little bass-heavy, it isn’t
overwhelming.

Audio-Technica stays true to its roots, ensuring that audio quality takes
precedence over headline-grabbing gimmicks. While it’s not a flashy set of
headphones, it includes the necessities to keep pace with the best of them
including Bluetooth 5 and aptX support.

Additionally, battery life is excellent; these lasted 31 hours and 12 minutes
on a single charge. If you’re looking for the best wireless headphones that
can do it all, the ATH-M50xBT is all you need.

## Who should buy Bluetooth headphones?

[![Focal Listen Wireless review: The headphones \(olive\) folded up and
resting in a bright green shrub.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/05/Focal_Listen-
Wireless_LK_7-1-1024x683.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/05/Focal_Listen-Wireless_LK_7-1.jpg)

The Focal Listen Wireless retail for $299 and are available in three
colorways: black, olive, blue, and purple.

  * _[Commuters](https://www.soundguys.com/best-bluetooth-headphones-for-commuting-29238/)._ If you spend a lot of time riding buses and trains, then you probably like to stay occupied with headphones. Well, cutting the cord makes blocking the world out that much easier.
  * _Office workers_. Let’s say you want a break from your cubicle but don’t want to engage in casual banter. Easy solution: grab a pair of wireless headphones. They notify others that you’re not up for talking without having to explicitly say so.
  * _Students_. Getting around campus can be a slow, monotonous process. You might as well exercise your mind and learn a thing or two from your [favorite podcast](https://www.soundguys.com/podcast-the-usb-c-trainwreck-18256/) while going from the quad to your English seminar.

## The V-Moda Crossfade 2 Wireless Codex are durable and versatile

The [V-Moda Crossfade 2 Wireless Codex](https://www.soundguys.com/v-moda-
crossfade-2-wireless-codex-18345/) are subject to military-level MIL-STD-810G
standards, ensuring durability throughout their lifetime. Aside from being
some of the toughest headphones on the market, the Crossfade 2 Codex are
versatile. [AAC](https://www.soundguys.com/the-ultimate-guide-to-bluetooth-
headphones-aac-20296/) and [aptX](https://www.soundguys.com/the-ultimate-
guide-to-bluetooth-aptx-and-aptx-hd-19914/) codec support in tandem with hi-
res certified wired listening make these the most durable best wireless
headphones for general consumers and audio enthusiasts alike.

## V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex

[Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/v-moda-crossfade-2-wireless-
codex-18345/)

Best Durability

![](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/07/V-Moda_Crossfade-2-Codex-4-1024x683.jpg)

  *   *   *   *   *   * 

V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex

8.5

[](https://tyvm.ly/9Img)

Beneath the exoskeleton case and steel exterior, the headphones are quite
comfortable. Much of the comfort is attributed to excellent headband
architecture and supple ear cushions. Be aware, though, you will feel the
weight of these after listening for about an hour or so.

> Even if the style isn’t for you, the functionality and versatility of these
> headphones deserves to be lauded.

Superb audio quality and durability aside, the layout of the controls is worth
appreciating. Seeing as most
[circumaural](https://www.soundguys.com/headphones-buying-guide-8290/)
headphones feature buttons that rest on the lateral edge of one of the ear
cups, the V-Moda Codex house the playback and volume controls so that they’re
aligned with the removable shield, thus forming an upside down V-shape. Aside
from looking good, the placement makes the buttons easy to differentiate and
find on the ear cup.

**Watch the video review[here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Se3_e7KN5u8)**

## The Sony WH-1000XM3 are the best noise cancelling headphones

For the past year this spot was occupied by the [Sony
WH-1000XM2](https://www.soundguys.com/sony-wh-1000x-m2-review-14304/)
headphones, but now they’ve been updated with the newer
[WH-1000XM3](https://www.soundguys.com/sony-wh-1000xm3-wireless-bluetooth-
headphones-review-19824/). It’s no surprise that these reign as one of the
best wireless headphones since they aren’t drastically different than their
predecessor. While the rumor is that the Sony WH-1000XM4 isn’t far off from
release, as of yet there’s nothing that makes us believe they’ll be released
before June. We could be wrong, but that may factor into your decision-making.

## Sony WH-1000XM3

[Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/sony-wh-1000xm3-wireless-bluetooth-
headphones-review-19824/)

Best Active Noise Cancelling

![](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/sony-
wh-1000x-m3-controls-1024x575.jpg)

  *   *   *   * 

Sony WH-1000XM3

8.8

[](https://tyvm.ly/eYwk)

With the WH-1000XM3, you get the same design and touch-sensitive ear cups for
adjusting volume and skipping between tracks. The two big differences between
the WH-1000XM2 and its predecessor are that the newer models now have deeper
ear cups which should help with isolation, and they charge via [USB
Type-C](https://www.soundguys.com/usb-audio-explained-18563/). The build
materials of the ear cup are also upgraded. Gone is the fake leather of the
previous model and instead, you’ll get a smooth plastic.

When you use the app, you can also make use of Sony’s 360 Reality Audio, which
when paired with partner streaming services, lets you listen to your music as
if it were all around you. It’s a brilliant feature, but requires the Sony
headphones app to work.

![](//i.ytimg.com/vi/MRviOQl_R4s/hqdefault.jpg)

Battery life is another key aspect of these headphones that got slightly
better. If you pick yourself up a pair of WH-1000XM3 headphones you can expect
a solid 24 hours of constant playback out of them. That’s with active noise
cancelling turned on as well, so these will have your back even on the longest
flights. Of course, the main issue that most people will have these is still
the price tag, but if you do decide to invest in one of the best wireless
headphones, you won’t be disappointed.

**Related:[Sony WH-1000XM3 or Bose QuietComfort 35
II?](https://www.soundguys.com/sony-wh-1000x-m3-or-bose-qc35-ii-which-to-
buy-22275/)**

## The best design goes to the Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700

While they didn’t dethrone the Sony WH-1000XM3 on our list of best noise
cancelling headphones, the Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700s are still
great. As the next iteration of the ANC line from Bose, these have a brand new
design that makes the QC35s before them seem ancient. The only downside is
that you no longer get any folding hinges, but you can still rotate the
earcups to lie flat and the new metal headband is much more durable.

## Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700

[Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/bose-noise-cancelling-
headphones-700-24897/)

Best design

![](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-Noise-
Cancelling-Headphones-700-6-2-1024x576.jpg)

  *   *   *   *   *   * 

Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700

8.5

[](https://geni.us/xX7c8Te)

The new design isn’t just for looks either. The playback control buttons have
been replaced by a touch-sensitive gesture pad on the right earcup for
controlling your music and the microphones inside have also been redesigned.
Our testing showed an impressive battery life of 21 hours which should get
most people through at least a week of commutes. Then there’s the active noise
cancelling, which is still one of the best around as is expected with a pair
of Bose headphones.

## **Looking to save some cash? Get the Anker SoundCore Vortex**

When it comes to finding the best wireless headphones, going the inexpensive
route may seem counterintuitive. Luckily, Anker specializes in bringing good
quality products at a lower price point, and the [Anker Soundcore
Vortex](https://www.soundguys.com/anker-soundcore-vortex-review-17679/) is no
different. They may not have a premium design or be as well-built as some of
the other options on this list, but they do have a bunch of great features
that hold their own against the big dogs.

## Anker Soundcore Vortex

[Full Review](https://www.soundguys.com/anker-soundcore-vortex-review-17679/)

Bang for your Buck

![](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Anker_Soundcore-
Vortex_LK_4-1024x683.jpg)

  *   *   * 

Anker Soundcore Vortex

8.1

[](https://tyvm.ly/fkKpr)

For one, these are compatible with Qualcomm’s aptX codec for streaming in
higher quality. They also have large, plush earcups for comfort and hinges to
help them fold down for a smaller footprint when traveling. But the most
impressive feature goes to the 20-hour battery life. If you’re not a fan of
plugging in headphones every night to charge, then these might be for you.

## How we picked the best wireless headphones

Choosing which product is best changes depending on what the category is. If
you’re searching for the [best headphones](https://www.soundguys.com/best-
over-ear-headphones-18379/), we might focus more of our efforts on sound
quality instead of cool extra features. On the flip side, if you’re looking
for the [best waterproof speakers](https://www.soundguys.com/waterproof-
speakers-8214/), chances are we’re going to prioritize a strong, durable build
over something like sound quality.

[![best wireless headphones Edifier W860NB: A hand on the touch panel of the
headphones.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/04/Edifier_W860NB-9-1024x575.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/04/Edifier_W860NB-9.jpg)

The Edifier W860NB, although a great set of headphones, couldn’t outperform
any of the top best wireless headphones picks.

For this particular list, there were a few things that took priority. First
was the Bluetooth connection. In order to be in the running for the best
wireless headphones, a strong connection was a must. After that came sound
quality. At the end of the day these are still headphones, and you’re going to
be using them to listen to music.

Additionally, we took user feedback on battery life into account when weeding
out products from our list. When we were writing our best [Bluetooth
earbuds](https://www.soundguys.com/best-bluetooth-earbuds-2018-2638/) best
list, our readers made it very clear that battery life was the most important
quality to assess after sound quality and comfort.

> Like
> [#Bluetooth](https://twitter.com/hashtag/Bluetooth?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)
> [#earbuds](https://twitter.com/hashtag/earbuds?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)?
> Comfort and sound quality aside, what's the most important thing they can
> have?
>
> — SoundGuys (@realsoundguys) [October 9,
> 2017](https://twitter.com/realsoundguys/status/917515928081960961?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

Bluetooth by itself has a bad rep when it comes to sound quality, but it’s
come a long way over the years, so anything on this list had to at the very
least sound good. Lastly, some of our decisions were made based on [internal
objective testing](https://www.soundguys.com/headphone-reviews-why-we-
test-18172/) of the best wireless headphones with special [software and
microphones](https://www.soundguys.com/how-we-test/).

**Related:[Best truly wireless earbud
headphones](https://www.soundguys.com/best-truly-wireless-earbuds-14313/)**

## What you should know about the best wireless headphones

The Sony MDR-1000XM3 have spectacular active noise cancelling, but what is it?
And how does it work? You can [dive deeper](https://www.soundguys.com/how-do-
noise-cancelling-headphones-work-12380/) if you’re really curious to learn the
science behind it, but if you don’t feel like dusting off your old textbook
and want the TL;DR version, here it is.

Tiny microphones built into the headphones pick up what’s going on around you
and then play the opposite sound wave into your ear along with your music.
Because the sound wave that’s produced by the headphones is basically the
exact opposite of the one that’s outside of the headphones, it cancels out.
Leaving you with just the sound of your blissful music. See? That wasn’t so
bad. Science can be cool.

[![A photo of a man wearing Sony WH-1000XM3
headphones.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/sony-
wh-1000x-m3-wear-1024x575.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/10/sony-wh-1000x-m3-wear.jpg)

The Sony WH-1000XM3’s exterior boasts a soft-touch material.

So you think you’re ready to understand what makes LDAC or [aptX
HD](https://www.soundguys.com/the-ultimate-guide-to-bluetooth-aptx-and-aptx-
hd-19914/) good? Get ready, there’s a ton of technical jargon and numbers
we’re about to go over, but we’ll try and keep it relatively short. For a full
breakdown make sure to check out [this great
article](https://www.soundguys.com/ldac-ultimate-bluetooth-guide-20026/) by
Rob Triggs over at our sister site _Android Authority_.

LDAC is supposed to be better is because it can [carry more audible
information](https://www.soundguys.com/audio-compression-explained-29148/)
than the standard SBC [codec](https://www.soundguys.com/understanding-
bluetooth-codecs-15352/), but our testing revealed that [LDAC isn’t completely
able to replace a wire](https://www.soundguys.com/ldac-ultimate-bluetooth-
guide-20026/). We’re still waiting to see if [aptX
Adaptive](https://www.soundguys.com/aptx-adaptive-explained-18768/) is going
to be as good as it seems, but luckily any issues are increasingly hard to
hear as we age because, sorry to break it to you, but [our ears aren’t that
great](https://www.soundguys.com/bluetooth-sounds-good-enough-20096/) when
we’re old.

[![Best wireless headphones: A chart showing the AAC Bluetooth codec's
performance on the Huawei P20 Pro, Samsung Galaxy Note 8, LG V30, and Apple
iPhone 7.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/aac-enhanced-
view-fr-1024x672.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/10/aac-enhanced-view-fr.jpg)

The AAC codec performance varies greatly depending on what source device is
being used.

Even if your phone doesn’t currently support it, you should still get
headphones that support these codecs anyway. Android 8.0 brings support for
these wireless standards to lots of [phones](https://www.soundguys.com/best-
smartphones-for-audio-16373/) in the near future and assuming your headphones
last longer than your smartphone does: your headphones will only sound better
as the tech in your phone catches up.

**Related:[Best headphones of 2019](https://www.soundguys.com/best-headphones-
of-2019-2559/)**

## Test results for the best wireless headphones

If you don’t feel like diving into each individual review but are still
interested in seeing the results for each pair of headphones, check out the
charts below. For those who are unfamiliar with how to read frequency
response, isolation, and microphone charts, be sure to checkout out
[explainer](https://www.soundguys.com/how-to-read-charts-23129/).

[![Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT frequency response
chart.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-
ath-m50xbt-frequency-response-
chart-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-frequency-response-
chart.jpg)

     Although the ATH-M50xBT headphones are a little bass-heavy, masking is minimal and audio quality is superb for Bluetooth headphones. 

[![Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT isolation chart.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-isolation-
chart-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-isolation-chart.jpg)

     The ATH-M50x can passively isolate some low-frequency noise. 

[![Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT microphone chart limited to the human voice
band.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-
ath-m50xbt-microphone-chart-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/03/audio-technica-ath-m50xbt-microphone-chart.jpg)

     The Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBT microphone frequency response chart limited to the human voice band. 

[![A chart showing the Bluetooth frequency response of the V-Moda Crossfade
Wireless II.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/v-moda-
crossfade-ii-frequency-response-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/07/v-moda-crossfade-ii-frequency-response.jpg)

     V-Moda is known for booming bass, but this time everything’s a little more tastefully restrained. 
  

[![A chart that shows the isolation performance of the V-Moda Crossfade
Wireless 2.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/v-moda-
crossfade-ii-isolation-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/07/v-moda-crossfade-ii-isolation.jpg)

     You’ll notice great isolation from mids and highs, but low notes will still overpower your music in noisy areas. 

[![A frequency response chart for the Sony WH-1000XM3's microphone performance
in the voice range.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/01/sony-wh-1000x-m3-microphone-Chart-Template-Relative-
voice-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/sony-
wh-1000x-m3-microphone-Chart-Template-Relative-voice.jpg)

     It’s too bad the headphones overuse dynamic compression to pick up quiet sounds, because otherwise the microphone on the Sone WH-1000XM3 is stellar. 

[![A chart showing the frequency response of the Sony WH-1000X
M3.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/sony-
wh-1000x-m3-frequency-response-
relative-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/01/sony-wh-1000x-m3-frequency-response-relative.jpg)

     Sony’s frequency response can be EQ’d in the app, but doing so automatically bumps playback down to SBC streaming. 

[![A chart detailing the noise canceling performance of the Sony WH-1000XM3
showing a much higher cancellation between 100Hz - 1000Hz when compared to the
Bose headphones.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/sony-
wh-1000x-m3-isolation-Chart-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2018/10/sony-wh-1000x-m3-isolation-Chart.jpg)

     The Sony WH-1000XM3 noise cancelling does a great job of quieting general ambient noise like chatter. 
  

[![The frequency response for the microphone shows a sharp drop off under
200Hz.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-700-FR-
Chart-voice-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-700-FR-Chart-voice.jpg)

     The Bose microphone does a good job with the main parts of voices, but anyone with a deep voice will be slightly cut off as frequencies less than 200Hz won’t be nearly as loud. 

[![The frequency response graph of the Bose 700 headphones show a slight
emphasis in the lows, but it isn't overdone.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-700-headphones-FR-
Chart-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-700-headphones-FR-Chart.jpg)

     The Bose 700 still has a slight emphasis on the low end, but combined with the isolating earcups it’s more than sufficient for all but the most hardcore bassheads. 

[![This isolation graph of the Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones 700 shows an
impressive cancelling of frequencies between 100-1000Hz with strong
cancellation above 1000Hz.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-700-headphones-
Isolation-150x150.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/07/Bose-700-headphones-Isolation.jpg)

     The more blue/green that you see, the more noise that was cancelled. The Bose 700 headphones do a good job with low end ambient sound, but still aren’t the best we’ve seen. 
  

## **Notable mentions**

[![Master & Dynamic MW65: Aerial image of the ear cups with one rotated,
resting flat against a table.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/05/Master-Dynamic_MW65-5_angled-aerial-ANC-
button-1024x575.jpg)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-
content/uploads/2019/05/Master-Dynamic_MW65-5_angled-aerial-ANC-button.jpg)

Users can choose between two noise cancelling modes depending on their
environments.

  * [_AKG N60 NC Wireless_](https://www.soundguys.com/akg-n60-nc-review-2-12666/) _:_ The N60 NC wireless headphones sound good, are comfortable, and are super portable. Definitely worth checking out if you’re always on the go.
  * _[Beyerdynamic Amiron Wireless](https://www.soundguys.com/beyerdynamic-amiron-wireless-review-17540/): _If you want to enjoy your music without being bothered by the sounds of the people you’re living with, these cans are for you. The Amiron Wireless supports AAC, aptX, and aptX HD.
  * _[Beyerdynamic Custom Game](https://www.soundguys.com/beyerdynamic-custom-game-review-16784/): _This headset is [great for gamers](https://www.soundguys.com/how-gaming-headsets-improve-20441/) who want the option to take their [gaming headphones](https://www.soundguys.com/best-gaming-headsets-12877/) to the streets. It includes a detachable boom mic and a selection of ear cup plates, plus it doesn’t look so gaudy that you can’t [wear it in public](https://www.soundguys.com/gaming-headset-guide-21951/).
  * _[Bose QuietComfort 35 II](https://www.soundguys.com/bose-qc35-ii-review-14264/)_ _:_ These active noise cancelling cans are neck-in-neck with the Sony WH-1000XM2 and feature a noise-rejecting, dual-mic system for clear voice recognition.
  * _[Edifier W860NB](https://www.soundguys.com/edifier-w860nb-review-22813/): _These headphones cost about half of the Sony WH-1000XM3 and provide excellent noise cancelling capabilities. While it doesn’t outperform the more expensive Sony cans, it’s a great alternative for those on a budget.
  * _[Focal Listen Wireless](https://www.soundguys.com/focal-listen-wireless-review-17544/):_ These aren’t cheap, but they are a solid pair of [over-ears](https://www.soundguys.com/headphones-buying-guide-8290/) with good sound, great battery life, and exceptional passive isolation.
  * [Grado GW100: ](https://www.soundguys.com/grado-gw100-review-20596/)Open-back wireless headphones are a perplexing product. After all, Bluetooth headphones that are also [open](https://www.soundguys.com/open-back-vs-closed-back-headphones-12179/) seem like an oxymoron, but because they grant you the freedom to move within your home or secluded office while enjoying high-quality, natural-sounding audio.
  * _[Master& Dynamic MW65](https://www.soundguys.com/master-dynamic-mw65-review-23897/):_ Master & Dynamic’s noise cancelling headphones are gorgeous. They support aptX for high-quality streaming and include an array of accessories.
  * [_Plantronics Backbeat FIT 6100_](https://www.soundguys.com/plantronics-backbeat-fit-6100-review-28680/): These are fairly affordable workout headphones that have warranted an IPX5 water-resistant rating. You get just under 27 hours of playtime from the headset and microphone quality is passable for most phone calls.
  * _[Shure AONIC 50](https://www.soundguys.com/shure-aonic-50-review-30744/):_ For the best low-frequency noise cancellation money can buy, poney up for the AONIC 50. These headphones are extremely comfortable to wear ([yes, even with glasses](https://www.soundguys.com/how-to-wear-headphones-with-glasses-30419/)), and they support all the high-quality Bluetooth codecs you could ever want.
  * [_Sony WH-1000XM2_](https://www.soundguys.com/sony-wh-1000x-m2-review-14304/) _:_ Just because there’s a newer version of these headphones available doesn’t mean that you shouldn’t consider the M2. They’re still a great pair of cans.

## Why you should trust us

In addition to the fact that this site is all of our day jobs, Adam, Chris,
and Lily have several years of reviewing consumer audio products under their
belts individually. Having kept a finger on the pulse of Bluetooth speakers
for several years allows us to be able to figure out what’s good, and what’s
best avoided.

[![Showing the Beyerdynamic Amiron Wireless falling off after shaking my
head.](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Beyer-
Amiron.gif)](https://www.soundguys.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Beyer-
Amiron.gif)

Shaking my head a little sends the headphones flying off.

Considering Chris’ burning hatred for wireless headphones, if he approves of
something—it’s damned special. In a similar vein, Adam has reviewed tons of
these headphones over the course of almost three years, so he’s heard the best
(and worst) of what the category has to offer. Then you’ve got Lily who has
put in countless hours working at a radio station in a professional studio
environment and even reviewed audio products on her own time before coming to
_SoundGuys_. Needless to say, she’s passionate about audio gear.

### Frequently Asked Questions

What's the best in-ear option?

Whether you're looking for [true wireless](https://www.soundguys.com/best-
truly-wireless-earbuds-14313/) or [wireless](https://www.soundguys.com/best-
wireless-earbuds-2638/) earbuds, the best will depend on the OS you have; what
use case you want the earbuds for; and how much you're willing to spend.
Listeners on a sub-$100 budget should get the [Anker SoundCore Liberty Air
2](http://tyvm.ly/t11UEt5). If you're willing to spend a bit more for [noise
cancellation](https://www.soundguys.com/noise-canceling-anc-explained-28344/),
the [Sony WF-1000XM3](https://geni.us/vuSaEhw) is great no matter what OS you
use, while iPhone users will get a streamlined experience from the [AirPods
Pro](https://www.soundguys.com/apple-airpods-pro-review-27106/). Want an
immediate pairing process on Android? Get the [Google Pixel
Buds](https://www.soundguys.com/apple-airpods-vs-google-pixel-
buds-2020-32454/).

Should I look for waterproof headphones?

If you're looking to use your [Bluetooth headphones for working
out](https://www.soundguys.com/best-bluetooth-workout-headphones-28771/), you
might want to find a pair with an official [IP
rating](https://www.soundguys.com/decoding-ip-ratings-16550/), or waterproof
rating. None of the Bluetooth headphones in this list have waterproofing of
any kind.

Will the Sony WH-1000XM3 work with a Bluetooth transmitter connected to a TV's
digital audio out?

It should!

How could you not have [insert model of headphones]?

Just because we didn't select a certain pair of headphones for this list
doesn't mean they're not good, it simply means they don't satisfy some set of
criteria to make them one of the five headphones we highlight. Maybe they
don't [test](https://www.soundguys.com/how-we-test/) as well as the ones on
the list, or they don't offer certain features that make them less appropriate
for it. I know that might not be a satisfying answer, but five headphones are
a pretty narrow selection for any category. Be sure to check out our reviews
if you want to learn more about any set of headphones you're looking for.
